column2: HTML - CSS, The Secret Sauce
What you'll do
Learn the basics of CSS, the "secret sauce" that makes styling web pages a snap! (Part 4)
I see my mention of a secret trick got you back here ^_^
Well, here it is - there's a way to automate all those "color=" and "font-size=" bits.
It's called CSS, and it's pretty awesome. Let's get rolling.
As always - if the previewer page doesn't open, try opening Chrome...
Or clicking the link - https://codepen.io/madetohack/pen/vYYyNba?editors=1000
You should notice a new section inside the `<head>` tag - `<style>`
Remember how we changed text colors, before? We used `style="color:green"` inside a tag.
The `<style>` tag takes all that manual work and centralizes it, like creating a set of rules.
Changing things inside the `<style>` tags tells the browser "when you see this tag, apply these changes to it."
Let's give it a shot, and make the first paragraph purple. Inside the `<style>` tag, type `p { color:purple; }`
Stylish! Now that we've got some kickin' purple text, let's make it bigger.
Add `font-size: x-large;` right after the color instruction. Don't forget a space between the instructions, or the semicolon (;) after each one.
That should read `p { color:purple; font-size: x-large; }`
Nice. Now *that's* got my attention.
You can do this for other tags, too - Use the name of the tag, an open brace ({), your styling, and then a closing brace (}).
Let's try making your `h1` text red.
To do that, you'd type  `h1 { color:red; }`
Great job! So, do you see how easy this can be, now?
It doesn't matter if you have an entire novel in that web page - it'll all be exactly as you say in the `<style>` tag.
There's still another level to climb to, though - What if I told you that you could make up your own tags?
Come back soon if you want to learn it!
